review.title: Conformant Planning as a Case Study of Incremental QBF Solving
review.abstract: We consider planning with uncertainty in the initial state as a case study of incremental quantified Boolean formula (QBF) solving. We report on experiments with a workflow to incrementally encode a planning instance into a sequence of QBFs. To solve this sequence of incrementally constructed QBFs, we use our general-purpose incremental QBF solver DepQBF. Since the generated QBFs have many clauses and variables in common, our approach avoids redundancy both in the encoding phase and in the solving phase. Experimental results show that incremental QBF solving outperforms non-incremental QBF solving. Our results are the first empirical study of incremental QBF solving in the context of planning. Based on our case study, we argue that incremental QBF solving also has the potential to improve QBF-based workflows in other application domains.
histories: revision (camera-ready, to appear in the proceedings of AISC 2014, volume 8884 of LNAI, Springer)
added reference to extended journal article; revision (camera-ready, to appear in the proceedings of AISC 2014, volume 8884 of LNAI, Springer)

sections.heading: 3 Conformant Planning and Benchmark Domains
sections.text: A compliant planning problem consists of a set of state variables over a specified domain, a set of measures with prerequisites and effects, an initial state in which some values of the variables may be unknown, and a specification of the target. The task is to find a sequence of measures, i.e., a plan that leads from the initial state to a state in which the target is fulfilled. The plan must meet the target for all possible values of unknown variables, i.e. it must be failsafe. This problem can be nicely encoded in QBFs, e.g. by building on the codes of cattle [33]. Conformal planning occurs naturally, e.g. in repair and therapy planning, where a plan must be successful even if some obstacles arise. The length of a plan is the number of measures in the plan. Since one usually looks for short plans, the following strategy is applied.

sections.heading: 4 QBF Planning Tool
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before in the history of the city.

sections.heading: 5 Experimental Evaluation
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before in the history of the city.

sections.heading: 5.1 Preprocessing
sections.text: Implementation of (inc) DepQBF does not include pre-processing [5,14]. In general, pre-processing could be very beneficial for the performance of QBF-based workflows. Efficient combination of pre-processing and incremental solving is part of ongoing research in SAT [21,30] and QBF [16,18,28,34]. To assess the potential impact of pre-processing in our workflow, we conducted the following experiment with DepQBF for all 288 planning instances with a time limit of 900 seconds and collected all QBFs generated this way. As for the results in Table 1, we executed DepQBF and incDepQBF on these QBFs within our workflow. Additionally, we executed the QBF solver Nenqfex [24] because it was well based on QBFF accumulated from the dungeon bench.5 Nenfex batteries.

sections.heading: 5.2 Comparison to Heuristic Approaches
sections.text: This year, it will be in a position to achieve the objectives I have mentioned.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We have presented a case study on the incremental QBF solution, which is based on a workflow for step-by-step encoding of planning problems in sequences of QBFs, thereby focusing on a universally valid QBF solver. The incremental approach avoids redundancy. First, parts of the QBF encoding of shorter plan lengths can be reused in the encoding of longer plan lengths. Second, the incremental QBF solver benefits from information learned from previously resolved QBFs. Compared to heuristic approaches, the QBF-based approach has the advantage of always finding the shortest plan and enabling the non-existence of a plan to be verified by Q-Resolution.6 Experiments with T0 were not performed on AMD Opteron 6176 SE, 2.3 GHz, 64-bit Linux with variants of the DepQBF solution approach.

Moreover, (inc)DepQBF and other search-based QBF solvers rely on Q-resolution [19] as the underlying proof system.
Given a Q-resolution proof Π of the unsatisfiability of a QBF ψ, it is possible to extract from Π a countermodel [2] or strategy [15] of ψ in terms of a set of Herbrand functions.

Given a conformant planning problem P , Qresolution proofs and Herbrand function countermodels allow to independently explain and verify [31] the non-existence of a plan (of a particular length) for P by verifying the unsatisfiability of the QBF encoding of P .

metadata.abstractText: We consider planning with uncertainty in the initial state as a case study of incremental quantified Boolean formula (QBF) solving. We report on experiments with a workflow to incrementally encode a planning instance into a sequence of QBFs. To solve this sequence of successively constructed QBFs, we use our general-purpose incremental QBF solver DepQBF. Since the generated QBFs have many clauses and variables in common, our approach avoids redundancy both in the encoding phase and in the solving phase. Experimental results show that incremental QBF solving outperforms non-incremental QBF solving. Our results are the first empirical study of incremental QBF solving in the context of planning and motivate its use in other application domains.
